 <!--l. 162845--> <h3 class="sectionHead"><span class="titlemark">50.4 </span> <a id="x309-163300050.4"></a><!--l. 162845--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">P</span></span></span></span></span></span>

versus <!--l. 162845--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.446em;">Q</span></span></span></span></span></span><img src="/lab/icons/icon_permalink.png" class="newIcon16 permaSlideplay iPermalink zindex155" permalink="about-quantitative-finance"><a href="/lab/redirect.php?slide=about-quantitative-finance" class="slide-zoom"><img src="icons/icon_present.png" alt="PIC" class="newIcon48 rightCol"></a><img src="/lab/icons/icon_permalink.png" permalink="about-quantitative-finance" class="newIcon16 permaTitle iPermalink"></h3>

<!--l. 162847--><p class="noindent">Quantitative techniques support all the steps of the &ldquo;Checklist&rdquo;&nbsp;of finance (<a href="executive-summary-checklist.html#x305-1618003r2" idtogo="1146" hash="#x305-1618003r2">Figure 50.2</a>).

</p><!--l. 162850--><p class="indent"> Quantitative techniques are omnipresent in risk management. In

essence, risk management amounts to learning the probability (denoted by

&ldquo;<!--l. 162851--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">P</span></span></span></span></span></span>&rdquo;) of a

variety of future outcomes. This goal can only be attained with sophisticated statistical tools,

jointly with financial engineering models.

</p><!--l. 162853--><p class="indent"> Quantitative techniques are also used in portfolio management, where not only advanced statistics

(<!--l. 162853--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">P</span></span></span></span></span></span>), but

also optimization theory plays an important role.

</p><!--l. 162855--><p class="indent"> Finally, quantitative techniques are heavily used for valuation purposes. In this

arena, the future risk/return profile of a given instrument determines the value of the

instrument, in one of two ways. First, using mathematical models again for the probability

<!--l. 162855--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">P</span></span></span></span></span></span> of

future outcomes, an approach followed by actuaries. Second, using mathematical models based on

the theory of arbitrage, an approach followed by desk quants for derivatives valuation. Arbitrage

theory in turn relies on a different probability of future outcomes, called risk-neutral and denoted

by &ldquo;<!--l. 162857--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.446em;">Q</span></span></span></span></span></span>&rdquo;.

</p><!--l. 162860--><p class="indent"> Despite the dominant role in quantitative finance of the

<!--l. 162860--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">P</span></span></span></span></span></span> (risk

management, portfolio management, and actuarial valuation), and the much more restricted role of the

<!--l. 162860--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.446em;">Q</span></span></span></span></span></span> (derivatives

valuation), the <!--l. 162860--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.446em;">Q</span></span></span></span></span></span>

applications have attracted a tremendous number of scientists to finance. As a result, from the 1980s to

the first decade of the 21st century, quantitative finance was identified with risk-neutral derivative

pricing. In more recent years, the financial industry has witnessed a surge of interest in quantitative

<!--l. 162861--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">P</span></span></span></span></span></span> models and a decrease

of interest in the <!--l. 162862--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.446em;">Q</span></span></span></span></span></span>.

</p><!--l. 162864--><p class="indent"> Given the importance of <!--l. 162864--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">P</span></span></span></span></span></span>

and <!--l. 162864--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.446em;">Q</span></span></span></span></span></span>

modeling in quantitative finance, we will now better clarify differences and similarities between

these two worlds, following <span class="cite">[<a href="Bibliography.html#XMeuPvsQ11" idtogo="39" hash="#XMeuPvsQ11">Meucci, 2011c</a>]</span>. </p><!--l. 162866--><p class="indent"> The main differences between <!--l. 162866--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">P</span></span></span></span></span></span>

and <!--l. 162866--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.446em;">Q</span></span></span></span></span></span>

quantitative finance can be summarized in the following table.

</p> <div class="table"> <!--l. 162871--><p class="indent"> </p><figure class="float"> <div class="center">

<!--l. 162871--><p class="noindent">

</p>

<div class="tabular"> <table id="TBL-2306" class="tabular"><colgroup id="TBL-2306-1g"><col id="TBL-2306-1"><col id="TBL-2306-2"><col id="TBL-2306-3"></colgroup><tbody><tr style="vertical-align:middle;" id="TBL-2306-1-"><td style="text-align:left; white-space:nowrap;" id="TBL-2306-1-1" class="td01"> </td><td style="text-align:center; white-space:nowrap;" id="TBL-2306-1-2" class="td11"> <b><span class="ecbx-1200">Risk/portfolio management</span></b> </td><td style="text-align:center; white-space:nowrap;" id="TBL-2306-1-3" class="td11"> <b><span class="ecbx-1200">Derivatives pricing</span></b> </td>

</tr><tr class="hline"><td><hr></td><td><hr></td><td><hr></td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:middle;" id="TBL-2306-2-"><td style="text-align:left; white-space:nowrap;" id="TBL-2306-2-1" class="td01">Goal </td><td style="text-align:center; white-space:nowrap;" id="TBL-2306-2-2" class="td11"> Forecast the future </td><td style="text-align:center; white-space:nowrap;" id="TBL-2306-2-3" class="td11"> Extrapolate the present </td>

</tr><tr style="vertical-align:middle;" id="TBL-2306-3-"><td style="text-align:left; white-space:nowrap;" id="TBL-2306-3-1" class="td01">Environment</td><td style="text-align:center; white-space:nowrap;" id="TBL-2306-3-2" class="td11">Real world probability <!--l. 162877--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">P</span></span></span></span></span></span></td><td style="text-align:center; white-space:nowrap;" id="TBL-2306-3-3" class="td11">Risk-neutral probability <!--l. 162878--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.446em;">Q</span></span></span></span></span></span></td>

</tr><tr style="vertical-align:middle;" id="TBL-2306-4-"><td style="text-align:left; white-space:nowrap;" id="TBL-2306-4-1" class="td01">Processes </td><td style="text-align:center; white-space:nowrap;" id="TBL-2306-4-2" class="td11"> Discrete-time series </td><td style="text-align:center; white-space:nowrap;" id="TBL-2306-4-3" class="td11"> Continuous-time martingales </td>

</tr><tr style="vertical-align:middle;" id="TBL-2306-5-"><td style="text-align:left; white-space:nowrap;" id="TBL-2306-5-1" class="td01">Dimension </td><td style="text-align:center; white-space:nowrap;" id="TBL-2306-5-2" class="td11"> Large </td><td style="text-align:center; white-space:nowrap;" id="TBL-2306-5-3" class="td11"> Small </td>

</tr><tr style="vertical-align:middle;" id="TBL-2306-6-"><td style="text-align:left; white-space:nowrap;" id="TBL-2306-6-1" class="td01">Tools </td><td style="text-align:center; white-space:nowrap;" id="TBL-2306-6-2" class="td11"> Multivariate statistics </td><td style="text-align:center; white-space:nowrap;" id="TBL-2306-6-3" class="td11"> It&ocirc; calculus, PDEs </td>

</tr><tr style="vertical-align:middle;" id="TBL-2306-7-"><td style="text-align:left; white-space:nowrap;" id="TBL-2306-7-1" class="td01">Challenges </td><td style="text-align:center; white-space:nowrap;" id="TBL-2306-7-2" class="td11"> Estimation </td><td style="text-align:center; white-space:nowrap;" id="TBL-2306-7-3" class="td11"> Calibration </td>

</tr><tr style="vertical-align:middle;" id="TBL-2306-8-"><td style="text-align:left; white-space:nowrap;" id="TBL-2306-8-1" class="td01">Business </td><td style="text-align:center; white-space:nowrap;" id="TBL-2306-8-2" class="td11"> Buy-side </td><td style="text-align:center; white-space:nowrap;" id="TBL-2306-8-3" class="td11"> Sell-side </td>

</tr><tr class="hline"><td><hr></td><td><hr></td><td><hr></td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:middle;" id="TBL-2306-9-"><td style="text-align:left; white-space:nowrap;" id="TBL-2306-9-1" class="td01"> </td></tr></tbody></table>

</div><img src="/lab/icons/icon_permalink.png" permalink="tabld-q-copy-1" class="newIcon16 permaRightCol iPermalink"><a id="x309-1633001r1"></a>

<figcaption class="caption"><span class="id">Table&nbsp;50.1: </span><span class="content"><!--l. 162889--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">P</span></span></span></span></span></span>

versus <!--l. 162889--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.446em;">Q</span></span></span></span></span></span>:

main differences of the two worlds of quantitative finance.

</span></figcaption><!--tex4ht:label?: x309-1633001r50.4 -->

</div> </figure> </div>

<!--l. 162899--><p class="indent"> We proceed to discuss the above differences.

</p> <h5 class="subsubsectionHead"><a id="x309-163400050.4"></a><!--l. 162901--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.446em;">Q</span></span></span></span></span></span>:

derivatives pricing<img src="/lab/icons/icon_permalink.png" permalink="sec-pqss-copy-1" class="newIcon16 permaTitle iPermalink"></h5>

<!--l. 162903--><p class="noindent">The goal of derivatives pricing is to determine the <span class="textcolor-DF4706">present</span> fair value of a given financial instrument

in terms of more liquid instruments whose value is determined by the law of supply and demand.

Derivatives pricing is a special instance of the more general problem of valuation, i.e. determining

the fair value of a given financial instrument.

</p><!--l. 162905--><p class="indent"> Examples of instruments to be priced are convertible bonds, exotic options, mortgage backed

securities, structured products, etc. Once a fair value has been determined, the sell-side [<a href="http://www.investopedia.com/ask/answers/04/040204.asp">W</a>] trader

can make a market [<a href="http://www.investopedia.com/terms/m/marketmaker.asp">W</a>] on the instrument. Therefore, pricing is a complex &lsquo;extrapolation&rsquo; exercise

to determine the current market value of a financial instrument, which is then used by the sell-side

community.

</p><!--l. 162920--><p class="indent"> Quantitative derivatives pricing was initiated by <span class="cite">[<a href="Bibliography.html#XBachelier1900" idtogo="39" hash="#XBachelier1900">Bachelier, 1900</a>]</span> with the introduction of the

most basic and most influential process, Brownian motion (<a href="efficiency-levy-processes.html#x213-1067007r41" idtogo="773" hash="#x213-1067007r41" res="formula">36.41<!--tex4ht:ref: basgdasga-copy-8 --></a>), and its applications to the

pricing of options. The theory remained dormant until <span class="cite">[<a href="Bibliography.html#XMerton69" idtogo="39" hash="#XMerton69">Merton, 1969</a>]</span> and <span class="cite">[<a href="Bibliography.html#XBlackScholes73" idtogo="39" hash="#XBlackScholes73">Black and Scholes, 1973</a>]</span>

applied the second most influential process, geometric Brownian motion (<a href="equities-exact-repricing-pricing.html#x360-1816009r64" idtogo="1292" hash="#x360-1816009r64" res="formula">55.64<!--tex4ht:ref: basgdasga-copy-1 --></a>), to option

pricing.

</p><!--l. 162923--><p class="indent"> The next important step is the fundamental theorem of asset pricing (<a href="section-fundamental-theorem-asset-pricing.html#x316-1664002r96" idtogo="1169" hash="#x316-1664002r96" res="formula">51a.96<!--tex4ht:ref: AMgsgdsdf --></a>), a simpler version

of which reads</p><table class="equation"><tbody><tr><td> <img src="/lab/icons/icon_permalink.png" permalink="asjjfalsdda" class="newIcon16 permaRightCol iPermalink"><a id="x309-1634001r82"></a>

<!--l. 162925--><span class="mjpage mjpage__block"><span class="mjx-chtml MJXc-display" style="text-align: center;"><span class="mjx-math equation" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mfrac"><span class="mjx-box MJXc-stacked" style="width: 2.884em; padding: 0px 0.12em;"><span class="mjx-numerator" style="width: 2.884em; top: -1.184em;"><span class="mjx-mrow"><span class="mjx-msub"><span class="mjx-base"><span class="mjx-mrow"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.225em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">v</span></span></span></span><span class="mjx-sub" style="font-size: 70.7%; vertical-align: -0.212em; padding-right: 0.071em;"><span class="mjx-mrow" style=""><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.372em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">t</span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mjx-denominator" style="width: 2.884em; bottom: -1.221em;"><span class="mjx-mrow"><span class="mjx-msup"><span class="mjx-base"><span class="mjx-mrow"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.225em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">e</span></span></span></span><span class="mjx-sup" style="font-size: 70.7%; vertical-align: 0.568em; padding-left: 0px; padding-right: 0.071em;"><span class="mjx-mrow" style=""><span class="mjx-msubsup"><span class="mjx-base" style="margin-right: -0.138em;"><span class="mjx-mrow"><span class="mjx-mo" style="padding-right: 0.138em;"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-size1-R" style="padding-top: 0.593em; padding-bottom: 0.593em;">&int;</span></span></span></span><span class="mjx-stack" style="vertical-align: -0.372em;"><span class="mjx-sup" style="font-size: 83.3%; padding-bottom: 0.33em; padding-left: 0.275em; padding-right: 0.06em;"><span class="mjx-mrow" style=""><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.372em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">t</span></span></span></span><span class="mjx-sub" style="font-size: 83.3%; padding-right: 0.06em;"><span class="mjx-mrow" style=""><span class="mjx-mn"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-main-R" style="padding-top: 0.372em; padding-bottom: 0.372em;">0</span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mjx-msub MJXc-space1"><span class="mjx-base"><span class="mjx-mrow"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.225em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">r</span></span></span></span><span class="mjx-sub" style="font-size: 83.3%; vertical-align: -0.18em; padding-right: 0.06em;"><span class="mjx-mrow" style=""><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.225em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">s</span></span></span></span></span><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em; padding-right: 0.003em;">d</span></span><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.225em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">s</span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span style="border-bottom: 1.3px solid; top: -0.296em; width: 2.884em;" class="mjx-line"></span></span><span style="height: 2.405em; vertical-align: -1.221em;" class="mjx-vsize"></span></span><span class="mjx-mo MathClass-rel MJXc-space3"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-main-R" style="padding-top: 0.077em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">=</span></span><span class="mjx-msubsup MJXc-space3"><span class="mjx-base"><span class="mjx-mrow"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">E</span></span></span></span><span class="mjx-stack" style="vertical-align: -0.287em;"><span class="mjx-sup" style="font-size: 70.7%; padding-bottom: 0.255em; padding-left: 0px; padding-right: 0.071em;"><span class="mjx-mrow" style=""><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.446em;">Q</span></span></span></span><span class="mjx-sub" style="font-size: 70.7%; padding-right: 0.071em;"><span class="mjx-mrow" style=""><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.372em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">t</span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mjx-mo MathClass-open"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-main-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.593em;">{</span></span><span class="mjx-mfrac"><span class="mjx-box MJXc-stacked" style="width: 3.008em; padding: 0px 0.12em;"><span class="mjx-numerator" style="width: 3.008em; top: -1.424em;"><span class="mjx-mrow"><span class="mjx-msub"><span class="mjx-base" style="margin-right: -0.186em;"><span class="mjx-mrow"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em; padding-right: 0.186em;">V</span></span></span></span><span class="mjx-sub" style="font-size: 70.7%; vertical-align: -0.212em; padding-right: 0.071em;"><span class="mjx-mrow" style=""><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.225em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">u</span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mjx-denominator" style="width: 3.008em; bottom: -1.112em;"><span class="mjx-mrow"><span class="mjx-msup"><span class="mjx-base"><span class="mjx-mrow"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.225em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">e</span></span></span></span><span class="mjx-sup" style="font-size: 70.7%; vertical-align: 0.568em; padding-left: 0px; padding-right: 0.071em;"><span class="mjx-mrow" style=""><span class="mjx-msubsup"><span class="mjx-base" style="margin-right: -0.138em;"><span class="mjx-mrow"><span class="mjx-mo" style="padding-right: 0.138em;"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-size1-R" style="padding-top: 0.593em; padding-bottom: 0.593em;">&int;</span></span></span></span><span class="mjx-stack" style="vertical-align: -0.372em;"><span class="mjx-sup" style="font-size: 83.3%; padding-bottom: 0.33em; padding-left: 0.275em; padding-right: 0.06em;"><span class="mjx-mrow" style=""><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.225em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">u</span></span></span></span><span class="mjx-sub" style="font-size: 83.3%; padding-right: 0.06em;"><span class="mjx-mrow" style=""><span class="mjx-mn"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-main-R" style="padding-top: 0.372em; padding-bottom: 0.372em;">0</span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mjx-msub MJXc-space1"><span class="mjx-base"><span class="mjx-mrow"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.225em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">r</span></span></span></span><span class="mjx-sub" style="font-size: 83.3%; vertical-align: -0.18em; padding-right: 0.06em;"><span class="mjx-mrow" style=""><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.225em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">s</span></span></span></span></span><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em; padding-right: 0.003em;">d</span></span><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.225em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">s</span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span style="border-bottom: 1.3px solid; top: -0.296em; width: 3.008em;" class="mjx-line"></span></span><span style="height: 2.536em; vertical-align: -1.112em;" class="mjx-vsize"></span></span><span class="mjx-mo MathClass-close"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-main-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.593em;">}</span></span><span class="mjx-mo MathClass-punc"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-main-R" style="margin-top: -0.144em; padding-bottom: 0.519em;">,</span></span><span class="mjx-mspace quad" style="width: 1em; height: 0px;"></span><span class="mjx-mi MJXc-space1"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.225em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">u</span></span><span class="mjx-mo MathClass-rel MJXc-space3"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-main-R" style="padding-top: 0.372em; padding-bottom: 0.446em;">&ge;</span></span><span class="mjx-mi MJXc-space3"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.372em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">t</span></span><span class="mjx-mstyle text"><span class="mjx-mrow"><span class="mjx-mtext"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-main-R" style="margin-top: -0.144em; padding-bottom: 0.372em;">.</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></td><td class="eq-no">(50.82)</td></tr></tbody></table>

<!--l. 162928--><p class="indent"> According to (<a href="#x309-1634001r82" idtogo="1150" hash="#x309-1634001r82" res="formula">50.82<!--tex4ht:ref: asjjfalsdda --></a>) the value <!--l. 162928--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-msub"><span class="mjx-base"><span class="mjx-mrow"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.225em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">v</span></span></span></span><span class="mjx-sub" style="font-size: 70.7%; vertical-align: -0.212em; padding-right: 0.071em;"><span class="mjx-mrow" style=""><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.372em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">t</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>

of an instrument is arbitrage-free, and thus truly fair, only if

<!--l. 162928--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-msub"><span class="mjx-base"><span class="mjx-mrow"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.225em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">v</span></span></span></span><span class="mjx-sub" style="font-size: 70.7%; vertical-align: -0.212em; padding-right: 0.071em;"><span class="mjx-mrow" style=""><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.372em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">t</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>, divided by the investment

<!--l. 162928--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-msup"><span class="mjx-base"><span class="mjx-mrow"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.225em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">e</span></span></span></span><span class="mjx-sup" style="font-size: 70.7%; vertical-align: 0.562em; padding-left: 0px; padding-right: 0.071em;"><span class="mjx-mrow" style=""><span class="mjx-msubsup"><span class="mjx-base"><span class="mjx-mrow"><span class="mjx-mi MathClass-op"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-main-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.593em; padding-right: 0.055em;">&int;</span></span><span class="mjx-mo"><span class="mjx-char"></span></span></span></span><span class="mjx-stack" style="vertical-align: -0.367em;"><span class="mjx-sup" style="font-size: 83.3%; padding-bottom: 0.216em; padding-left: 0px; padding-right: 0.06em;"><span class="mjx-mrow" style=""><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.372em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">t</span></span></span></span><span class="mjx-sub" style="font-size: 83.3%; padding-right: 0.06em;"><span class="mjx-mrow" style=""><span class="mjx-mn"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-main-R" style="padding-top: 0.372em; padding-bottom: 0.372em;">0</span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mjx-msub"><span class="mjx-base"><span class="mjx-mrow"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.225em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">r</span></span></span></span><span class="mjx-sub" style="font-size: 83.3%; vertical-align: -0.18em; padding-right: 0.06em;"><span class="mjx-mrow" style=""><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.225em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">s</span></span></span></span></span><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em; padding-right: 0.003em;">d</span></span><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.225em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">s</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> which has instantaneous

risk-free return rate <!--l. 162928--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-msub"><span class="mjx-base"><span class="mjx-mrow"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.225em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">r</span></span></span></span><span class="mjx-sub" style="font-size: 70.7%; vertical-align: -0.212em; padding-right: 0.071em;"><span class="mjx-mrow" style=""><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.372em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">t</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>,

can be written as the expected value (under a suitable probability measure) of the same ratio at any

future time <!--l. 162928--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.225em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">u</span></span></span></span></span></span>. </p><!--l. 162930--><p class="indent"> A process such as the ratio in (<a href="#x309-1634001r82" idtogo="1150" hash="#x309-1634001r82" res="formula">50.82<!--tex4ht:ref: asjjfalsdda --></a>) is called a martingale (<a href="martingale-process-cheat-sheet.html#x215-1084006r105" idtogo="786" hash="#x215-1084006r105" res="formula">36.105<!--tex4ht:ref: sftaog-copy-3 --></a>). The relationship (<a href="#x309-1634001r82" idtogo="1150" hash="#x309-1634001r82" res="formula">50.82<!--tex4ht:ref: asjjfalsdda --></a>)

must hold for all times, therefore the processes used for derivatives pricing are naturally set in

continuous time.

</p><!--l. 162933--><p class="indent"> The martingale (<a href="#x309-1634001r82" idtogo="1150" hash="#x309-1634001r82" res="formula">50.82<!--tex4ht:ref: asjjfalsdda --></a>) does not reward risk: the expected return of the risky investment

<!--l. 162933--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-msub"><span class="mjx-base" style="margin-right: -0.186em;"><span class="mjx-mrow"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em; padding-right: 0.186em;">V</span></span></span></span><span class="mjx-sub" style="font-size: 70.7%; vertical-align: -0.212em; padding-right: 0.071em;"><span class="mjx-mrow" style=""><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.372em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">t</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>

over each subsequent step is the risk-free rate at that point in time:

<!--l. 162933--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-msubsup"><span class="mjx-base"><span class="mjx-mrow"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">E</span></span></span></span><span class="mjx-stack" style="vertical-align: -0.287em;"><span class="mjx-sup" style="font-size: 70.7%; padding-bottom: 0.255em; padding-left: 0px; padding-right: 0.071em;"><span class="mjx-mrow" style=""><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.446em;">Q</span></span></span></span><span class="mjx-sub" style="font-size: 70.7%; padding-right: 0.071em;"><span class="mjx-mrow" style=""><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.372em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">t</span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mjx-mo MathClass-open"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-main-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.593em;">{</span></span><span class="mjx-msub"><span class="mjx-base" style="margin-right: -0.186em;"><span class="mjx-mrow"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em; padding-right: 0.186em;">V</span></span></span></span><span class="mjx-sub" style="font-size: 70.7%; vertical-align: -0.219em; padding-right: 0.071em;"><span class="mjx-mrow" style=""><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.372em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">t</span></span><span class="mjx-mo MathClass-bin"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-main-R" style="padding-top: 0.298em; padding-bottom: 0.446em;">+</span></span><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em; padding-right: 0.003em;">d</span></span><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.372em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">t</span></span></span></span></span><span class="mjx-mo MathClass-bin MJXc-space2"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-main-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.593em;">&#8725;</span></span><span class="mjx-msub MJXc-space2"><span class="mjx-base"><span class="mjx-mrow"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.225em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">v</span></span></span></span><span class="mjx-sub" style="font-size: 70.7%; vertical-align: -0.212em; padding-right: 0.071em;"><span class="mjx-mrow" style=""><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.372em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">t</span></span></span></span></span><span class="mjx-mo MathClass-close"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-main-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.593em;">}</span></span><span class="mjx-mo MathClass-bin MJXc-space2"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-main-R" style="padding-top: 0.298em; padding-bottom: 0.446em;">&minus;</span></span><span class="mjx-mn MJXc-space2"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-main-R" style="padding-top: 0.372em; padding-bottom: 0.372em;">1</span></span><span class="mjx-mo MathClass-rel MJXc-space3"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-main-R" style="padding-top: 0.077em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">=</span></span><span class="mjx-msub MJXc-space3"><span class="mjx-base"><span class="mjx-mrow"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.225em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">r</span></span></span></span><span class="mjx-sub" style="font-size: 70.7%; vertical-align: -0.212em; padding-right: 0.071em;"><span class="mjx-mrow" style=""><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.372em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">t</span></span></span></span></span><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em; padding-right: 0.003em;">d</span></span><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.372em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">t</span></span></span></span></span></span>.

Thus the probability measure which makes the normalized price process a martingale

is referred to as &ldquo;risk-neutral&rdquo;&nbsp;and is typically denoted by the blackboard font letter

&ldquo;<!--l. 162934--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.446em;">Q</span></span></span></span></span></span>&rdquo;.

</p><!--l. 162937--><p class="indent"> The risk-neutral measure can be obtained from the process of the underlying instrument, for

example: from a geometric Brownian motion of a stock (<a href="equities-exact-repricing-pricing.html#x360-1816009r64" idtogo="1292" hash="#x360-1816009r64" res="formula">55.64<!--tex4ht:ref: basgdasga-copy-1 --></a>).

</p><!--l. 162940--><p class="indent"> The derivative pricing quants who operate in the

<!--l. 162940--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.446em;">Q</span></span></span></span></span></span>

world are specialists with deep knowledge of the specific products they

model. Instruments are priced individually, and thus the problems in the

<!--l. 162941--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.446em;">Q</span></span></span></span></span></span> world

are low-dimensional in nature.

</p><!--l. 162944--><p class="indent"> Calibration is one of the main challenges in the

<!--l. 162944--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.446em;">Q</span></span></span></span></span></span> world:

once a continuous-time parametric process has been calibrated to a set of traded instruments

through a relationship such as (<a href="#x309-1634001r82" idtogo="1150" hash="#x309-1634001r82" res="formula">50.82<!--tex4ht:ref: asjjfalsdda --></a>), a similar relationship is used to define&nbsp;the values of new

derivatives.

</p><!--l. 162946--><p class="indent"> The main quantitative tools necessary to handle continuous-time

<!--l. 162946--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.446em;">Q</span></span></span></span></span></span> processes

are It&ocirc;&rsquo;s stochastic calculus, partial differential equations (PDEs), partial integro-differential

equations (PIDEs), Fourier and Laplace analysis, etc. Throughout the past decades, these advanced

techniques have attracted mathematicians, physicists, and engineers to the field of derivatives pricing in

the <!--l. 162948--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.446em;">Q</span></span></span></span></span></span>

world.

</p><!--l. 162950--><p class="noindent">

</p> <h5 class="subsubsectionHead"><a id="x309-163500050.4"></a><!--l. 162950--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">P</span></span></span></span></span></span>:

quantitative risk and portfolio management<img src="/lab/icons/icon_permalink.png" permalink="SecPQSs" class="newIcon16 permaTitle iPermalink"></h5>

<!--l. 162952--><p class="noindent">Risk management and portfolio management aim to forecast and improve the distribution of <span class="textcolor-DF4706">future</span>

returns. This real world probability distribution is typically denoted by the blackboard font letter

&ldquo;<!--l. 162953--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">P</span></span></span></span></span></span>&rdquo;.

</p><!--l. 162955--><p class="indent"> Based on the <!--l. 162955--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">P</span></span></span></span></span></span>

distribution, the asset management, or buy-side [<a href="http://www.investopedia.com/ask/answers/04/040204.asp">W</a>], community makes decisions on which financial

instruments to purchase/sell, in order to improve the prospective profit-and-loss (P&amp;L) profile of their portfolio.&nbsp;Similarly, the banks and insurance companies decide based on the

<!--l. 162963--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">P</span></span></span></span></span></span>

distribution which business lines to invest in.

</p><!--l. 162965--><p class="indent"> The quantitative theory of risk and portfolio management started with the mean-variance

framework of <span class="cite">[<a href="Bibliography.html#XMarkowitz52" idtogo="39" hash="#XMarkowitz52">Markowitz, 1952</a>]</span>.&nbsp;Next, breakthrough advances were made with the capital asset

pricing model (CAPM) and the arbitrage pricing theory (APT)&nbsp;developed by <span class="cite">[<a href="Bibliography.html#XTreynor62" idtogo="39" hash="#XTreynor62">Treynor, 1962</a>]</span>,

<span class="cite">[<a href="Bibliography.html#XMossin66" idtogo="39" hash="#XMossin66">Mossin, 1966</a>]</span>, <span class="cite">[<a href="Bibliography.html#XSharpe64" idtogo="39" hash="#XSharpe64">Sharpe, 1964</a>]</span>, <span class="cite">[<a href="Bibliography.html#XLintner65" idtogo="39" hash="#XLintner65">Lintner, 1965</a>]</span>, and <span class="cite">[<a href="Bibliography.html#XRoss76" idtogo="39" hash="#XRoss76">Ross, 1976</a>]</span>.

</p><!--l. 162968--><p class="indent"> The above theories provide tremendous insight into the

markets. However, they all assume that the probability distribution

<!--l. 162968--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">P</span></span></span></span></span></span> is known. In reality, the

probability distribution <!--l. 162968--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">P</span></span></span></span></span></span>

must be estimated from available information.&nbsp;A major component of this information set is based

on the past dynamics of values and other financial variables which are monitored at discrete time

intervals and stored in the form of time series.

</p><!--l. 162970--><p class="indent"> Estimation represents the main quantitative challenge in the

<!--l. 162970--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">P</span></span></span></span></span></span>

world of risk and portfolio management. Estimation is based on the observation of the

time series of multiple risk drivers. The analysis of time series requires advanced

multivariate statistical and econometric techniques. Note that in risk and portfolio

management it is important to estimate the <span class="textcolor-DF4706">joint</span> distribution of all the instruments in that

market, and thus financial instruments cannot be considered individually. Therefore

dimension reduction techniques such as linear factor models play a central role in the

<!--l. 162973--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">P</span></span></span></span></span></span>

world.

</p><!--l. 162975--><p class="indent"> To address the above issues, in recent years a new breed of quants, the

<!--l. 162976--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">P</span></span></span></span></span></span>

quants, has started to populate the financial industry, and more

<!--l. 162977--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">P</span></span></span></span></span></span> quants

are being trained in the same master&rsquo;s degree programs that were originally designed to train

<!--l. 162977--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.446em;">Q</span></span></span></span></span></span>

quants.

</p><!--l. 162980--><p class="noindent">

</p> <h5 class="subsubsectionHead"><a id="x309-163600050.4"></a>Commonalities between <!--l. 162980--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">P</span></span></span></span></span></span>

and <!--l. 162980--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.446em;">Q</span></span></span></span></span></span><img src="/lab/icons/icon_permalink.png" permalink="commonalities-between-p-and-q" class="newIcon16 permaTitle iPermalink"></h5>

<!--l. 162982--><p class="noindent">From a comparison of the columns in <a href="#x309-1633001r1" idtogo="1150" hash="#x309-1633001r1">Table 50.1</a>, it appears as though

<!--l. 162983--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">P</span></span></span></span></span></span> and

<!--l. 162983--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.446em;">Q</span></span></span></span></span></span> are

very different. In reality, commonalities between these two worlds abound and interactions occur

frequently in different areas.<br class="newline"></p><div class="table"> <!--l. 162987--><p class="indent"> </p><figure class="float"> <div class="center">

<!--l. 162987--><p class="noindent">

</p>

<div class="tabular"> <table id="TBL-2307" class="tabular"><colgroup id="TBL-2307-1g"><col id="TBL-2307-1"><col id="TBL-2307-2"></colgroup><tbody><tr style="vertical-align:middle;" id="TBL-2307-1-"><td style="text-align:left; white-space:nowrap;" id="TBL-2307-1-1" class="td00">Area of <!--l. 162992--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">P</span></span></span></span></span></span>-<!--l. 162992--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.446em;">Q</span></span></span></span></span></span> commonality </td><td style="text-align:left; white-space:nowrap;" id="TBL-2307-1-2" class="td01">Specific <!--l. 162992--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">P</span></span></span></span></span></span>-<!--l. 162993--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.446em;">Q</span></span></span></span></span></span> overlap </td>

</tr><tr class="hline"><td><hr></td><td><hr></td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:middle;" id="TBL-2307-2-"><td style="text-align:left; white-space:nowrap;" id="TBL-2307-2-1" class="td00">Risk premium </td><td style="text-align:left; white-space:nowrap;" id="TBL-2307-2-2" class="td01">Switch between <!--l. 162993--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">P</span></span></span></span></span></span> and <!--l. 162993--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.446em;">Q</span></span></span></span></span></span></td>

</tr><tr style="vertical-align:middle;" id="TBL-2307-3-"><td style="text-align:left; white-space:nowrap;" id="TBL-2307-3-1" class="td00">Stochastic processes </td><td style="text-align:left; white-space:nowrap;" id="TBL-2307-3-2" class="td01">Discrete and continuous time </td>

</tr><tr style="vertical-align:middle;" id="TBL-2307-4-"><td style="text-align:left; white-space:nowrap;" id="TBL-2307-4-1" class="td00">Numerical methods </td><td style="text-align:left; white-space:nowrap;" id="TBL-2307-4-2" class="td01">Trees, Monte Carlo </td>

</tr><tr style="vertical-align:middle;" id="TBL-2307-5-"><td style="text-align:left; white-space:nowrap;" id="TBL-2307-5-1" class="td00">Hedging </td><td style="text-align:left; white-space:nowrap;" id="TBL-2307-5-2" class="td01">Greeks </td>

</tr><tr style="vertical-align:middle;" id="TBL-2307-6-"><td style="text-align:left; white-space:nowrap;" id="TBL-2307-6-1" class="td00">Statistical arbitrage </td><td style="text-align:left; white-space:nowrap;" id="TBL-2307-6-2" class="td01">Pricing-based mean-reversion </td>

</tr><tr style="vertical-align:middle;" id="TBL-2307-7-"><td style="text-align:left; white-space:nowrap;" id="TBL-2307-7-1" class="td00">Algorithmic trading </td><td style="text-align:left; white-space:nowrap;" id="TBL-2307-7-2" class="td01">Applied to buy-side and sell-side </td>

</tr><tr class="hline"><td><hr></td><td><hr></td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:middle;" id="TBL-2307-8-"><td style="text-align:left; white-space:nowrap;" id="TBL-2307-8-1" class="td00"> </td></tr></tbody></table>

</div><img src="/lab/icons/icon_permalink.png" permalink="TablCommonPQ" class="newIcon16 permaRightCol iPermalink"><a id="x309-1636001r2"></a>

<figcaption class="caption"><span class="id">Table&nbsp;50.2: </span><span class="content"><!--l. 163004--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">P</span></span></span></span></span></span>

versus <!--l. 163004--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.446em;">Q</span></span></span></span></span></span>:

main commonalities of the two worlds of quantitative finance.

</span></figcaption><!--tex4ht:label?: x309-1636001r50.4 -->

</div> </figure> </div>

<!--l. 163014--><p class="indent"> We proceed to discuss the above commonalities, pointing to the areas in the present work where

we address them in detail.

</p> <h5 class="subsubsectionHead"><a id="x309-163700050.4"></a>Risk premium<img src="/lab/icons/icon_permalink.png" permalink="SecRiskPrem" class="newIcon16 permaTitle iPermalink"></h5>

<!--l. 163018--><p class="noindent">Mathematically, the risk-neutral probability <!--l. 163018--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.446em;">Q</span></span></span></span></span></span>

and the real world probability <!--l. 163018--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">P</span></span></span></span></span></span>

associate different weights to the same possible outcomes for the same financial variables. The

transition from one set of probability weights to the other defines the so-called &ldquo;risk

premium&rdquo;.&nbsp;Knowledge of the risk premium allows us in principle to switch from one world to

the other. Unfortunately, the correct estimation of the risk premium is a challenging

task.

</p><!--l. 163020--><p class="indent"> We define risk premium in the context of risk assessment in <a href="satisfaction-regular-markets.html#x379-189900057.2" idtogo="1356" hash="#x379-189900057.2">Section 57.2</a>. We then use risk

premium in valuation theory: arbitrage pricing theory (APT) in <a href="linear-factor-models-arbitrage-pricing-theory.html#x320-167600051a.8" idtogo="1183" hash="#x320-167600051a.8">Section 51a.8</a> and actuarial

valuation in <a href="pricing-points-of-interest.html#x322-168500051a.10.1" idtogo="1191" hash="#x322-168500051a.10.1">Chapter 51a.10.1</a>. We also use risk premium in the context of systematic strategies in

<a href="construction-cross-sectional-strategies.html#x421-210300060c" idtogo="1491" hash="#x421-210300060c">Chapter 60c</a>.

</p><!--l. 163027--><p class="noindent">

</p> <h5 class="subsubsectionHead"><a id="x309-163800050.4"></a>Stochastic processes<img src="/lab/icons/icon_permalink.png" permalink="SecStochasticProc" class="newIcon16 permaTitle iPermalink"></h5>

<!--l. 163029--><p class="noindent">Stochastic processes are the building blocks of any quantitative model, both in the

<!--l. 163029--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">P</span></span></span></span></span></span> world and in the

<!--l. 163029--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.446em;">Q</span></span></span></span></span></span> world. Although

<!--l. 163029--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.446em;">Q</span></span></span></span></span></span> quants focus on continuous

risk-neutral processes and <!--l. 163030--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">P</span></span></span></span></span></span>

quants focus on discrete-time processes, the same models are used in both areas, possibly under

different assumptions and names. <a href="quest-for-invariance.html#x343-1752021r1" idtogo="1240" hash="#x343-1752021r1">Table 53a.1</a> summarizes the main features of the most popular

models.

</p><!--l. 163034--><p class="indent"> We discuss stochastic processes in <a href="stochastic-processes-part.html#x204-1028000VII" idtogo="745" hash="#x204-1028000VII">Part VII</a>.

</p><!--l. 163037--><p class="noindent">

</p> <h5 class="subsubsectionHead"><a id="x309-163900050.4"></a>Numerical methods<img src="/lab/icons/icon_permalink.png" permalink="SecNumMethodes" class="newIcon16 permaTitle iPermalink"></h5>

<!--l. 163039--><p class="noindent">The theoretical stochastic processes discussed above must be implemented in practice.

In order to do so, the most popular numerical techniques are <span class="textcolor-DF4706">trees</span> and <span class="textcolor-DF4706">Monte Carlo</span>

simulations. </p><!--l. 163042--><p class="indent"> Trees represent a process as an ever-expanding sequence of potential outcomes: the state of the

world today will give rise to multiple possible outcomes tomorrow; each of these in turn will give

rise to multiple possible outcomes the day after tomorrow, and so on. In general, with trees

the number of potential outcomes (or nodes) grows exponentially as the time horizon

increases. Instead, with Monte&nbsp;Carlo simulations, the number of possible outcomes, also

known as <span class="textcolor-DF4706">paths</span>, of a stochastic process is kept constant throughout the evolution of the

process.

</p><!--l. 163044--><p class="indent"> The computationally more costly trees are used when it is important to make

decisions along the trajectory of the stochastic process, whereas Monte&nbsp;Carlo

is used when only the process distribution is required.&nbsp;Therefore, in the

<!--l. 163045--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">P</span></span></span></span></span></span> world

of risk and portfolio management, trees are used to design dynamic strategies, whereas

Monte Carlo is used for risk monitoring purposes, such as value-at-risk computations. In

the&nbsp;<!--l. 163046--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.446em;">Q</span></span></span></span></span></span>

world, trees are used for instance to price <span class="textcolor-DF4706">American</span> options, which can be exercised before expiry,

whereas Monte Carlo is used to price <span class="textcolor-DF4706">Asian</span> options, i.e. options on the average value of an

underlying instrument over a pre-specified period of time.

</p><!--l. 163049--><p class="indent"> We discuss Monte Carlo simulations in <a href="monte-carlo-scenario-based-projection.html#x247-123600042.1" idtogo="902" hash="#x247-123600042.1">Section 42.1</a> and dynamic strategies in&nbsp;<a href="construction-time-series-strategies.html#x429-213500060d" idtogo="1512" hash="#x429-213500060d">Chapter

60d</a>.

</p><!--l. 163054--><p class="noindent">

</p> <h5 class="subsubsectionHead"><a id="x309-164000050.4"></a>Hedging<img src="/lab/icons/icon_permalink.png" permalink="SecHedging" class="newIcon16 permaTitle iPermalink"></h5>

<!--l. 163056--><p class="noindent">Hedging is a clear example where the <!--l. 163056--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">P</span></span></span></span></span></span>

world and the <!--l. 163056--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.446em;">Q</span></span></span></span></span></span>

world interact directly.

</p><!--l. 163059--><p class="indent"> Hedging aims to protect the future P&amp;L of a given position from a set of risk factors. Therefore,

hedging is a <!--l. 163059--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">P</span></span></span></span></span></span>

world concept.

</p><!--l. 163061--><p class="indent"> In order to determine the amounts of the hedging instruments to buy or sell, we need to

compute the sensitivity of the given position and of the hedging instruments to those risk

factors.

</p><!--l. 163064--><p class="indent"> Such sensitivities are known as the &ldquo;Greeks&rdquo;. The most basic Greek&nbsp;is the &ldquo;delta&rdquo;&nbsp;of an option

written on a given financial instrument, which is the sensitivity of the option to the

underlying value. The delta of an option tells the trader how much of the underlying

instrument to buy or to sell in order to protect the option from swings in the underlying

value.

</p><!--l. 163067--><p class="indent"> The Greeks are computed using pricing models from the

<!--l. 163067--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.446em;">Q</span></span></span></span></span></span> world and then applied in the

<!--l. 163067--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">P</span></span></span></span></span></span> world for hedging. Interestingly,

those very same <!--l. 163067--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.446em;">Q</span></span></span></span></span></span> world pricing models can be derived based on the <!--l. 163068--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">P</span></span></span></span></span></span>

world concept of hedging.

</p><!--l. 163070--><p class="indent"> We discuss hedging in the context of risk attribution in <a href="applications-performance.html#x396-199200058a.5" idtogo="1410" hash="#x396-199200058a.5">Section 58a.5</a>.

</p><!--l. 163073--><p class="noindent">

</p> <h5 class="subsubsectionHead"><a id="x309-164100050.4"></a>Statistical arbitrage<img src="/lab/icons/icon_permalink.png" permalink="SecStatArbitrage" class="newIcon16 permaTitle iPermalink"></h5>

<!--l. 163075--><p class="noindent">The <!--l. 163075--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.446em;">Q</span></span></span></span></span></span> world has also

moved into the <!--l. 163075--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">P</span></span></span></span></span></span>

world in the area of statistical arbitrage algorithms. The general steps of this interaction are as

follows.

</p><!--l. 163077--><p class="indent"> First, <!--l. 163077--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.446em;">Q</span></span></span></span></span></span>

models (or other tools) are used to identify misalignments between the values of financial

instruments today. Second, one assumes that the misaligned values will eventually converge to

the values indicated by the models. Therefore, a potential expected return in the real

<!--l. 163077--><span class="mjpage"><span class="mjx-chtml"><span class="mjx-math" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-ams-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">P</span></span></span></span></span></span> world,

or &ldquo;alpha&rdquo;, is identified as the difference between the indicated values (the future, &ldquo;fair&rdquo;&nbsp;value) and

the current misaligned values. Third, if the alpha is positive, a long position is set up, i.e. the

misaligned instruments are bought, in the expectation that they will reach their higher fair value

and thus realize a profit; if the alpha is negative, a short position is set up, i.e. the misaligned

instruments are sold.

</p><!--l. 163080--><p class="indent"> We discuss statistical arbitrage in the context of cointegration in <a href="multivariate-quest-invariants.html#x353-177800053b.1.2" idtogo="1262" hash="#x353-177800053b.1.2">Section 53b.1.2</a>.

</p><!--l. 163083--><p class="noindent">

</p> <h5 class="subsubsectionHead"><a id="x309-164200050.4"></a>Algorithmic trading<img src="/lab/icons/icon_permalink.png" permalink="SecAlgoTrading" class="newIcon16 permaTitle iPermalink"></h5>

<!--l. 163085--><p class="noindent">Historically, sell-side market makers have implemented algorithms to provide liquidity to the

market, while charging a premium for their sell-side services. On the other hand, buy-side

high-frequency traders have implemented algorithms that efficiently execute orders, absorbing

liquidity and delivering profits.

</p><!--l. 163087--><p class="indent"> More recently, the distinction between sell-side and buy-side has become blurry, as the two

groups are becoming competitors.

</p><!--l. 163089--><p class="indent"> We discuss algorithmic trading in the context of optimal execution in <a href="lbl-execution.html#x436-215400061" idtogo="1531" hash="#x436-215400061">Chapter 61</a>. </p> <!--l. 163092-->

<!--l. 163092--><p class="indent"> <a id="tailarpm20241217082824pse247.html"></a> </p> 


<div id="formulasContainer"><div class="divFormula" hash="x213-1067007r41"><span class="mjpage mjpage__block"><span class="mjx-chtml MJXc-display" style="text-align: center;"><span class="mjx-math equation" aria-label="Equation"><span class="mjx-mrow" aria-hidden="true"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em; padding-right: 0.003em;">d</span></span><span class="mjx-msub"><span class="mjx-base" style="margin-right: -0.024em;"><span class="mjx-mrow"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em; padding-right: 0.024em;">X</span></span></span></span><span class="mjx-sub" style="font-size: 70.7%; vertical-align: -0.212em; padding-right: 0.071em;"><span class="mjx-mrow" style=""><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.372em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">t</span></span></span></span></span><span class="mjx-mo MathClass-rel MJXc-space3"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-main-R" style="padding-top: 0.077em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">=</span></span><span class="mjx-mi MJXc-space3"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.225em; padding-bottom: 0.519em;">&mu;</span></span><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em; padding-right: 0.003em;">d</span></span><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.372em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">t</span></span><span class="mjx-mo MathClass-bin MJXc-space2"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-main-R" style="padding-top: 0.298em; padding-bottom: 0.446em;">+</span></span><span class="mjx-mi MJXc-space2"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.225em; padding-bottom: 0.298em; padding-right: 0.001em;">&sigma;</span></span><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em; padding-right: 0.003em;">d</span></span><span class="mjx-msub"><span class="mjx-base"><span class="mjx-mrow"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">B</span></span></span></span><span class="mjx-sub" style="font-size: 70.7%; vertical-align: -0.212em; padding-right: 0.071em;"><span class="mjx-mrow" style=""><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.372em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">t</span></span></span></span></span><span class="mjx-mo MathClass-rel MJXc-space3"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-main-R" style="padding-top: 0.077em; padding-bottom: 0.298em;">&sim;</span></span><span class="mjx-mstyle MJXc-space3"><span class="mjx-mrow"><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.298em; padding-right: 0.085em;">N</span></span></span></span><span class="mjx-mo MathClass-open"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-main-R" style="padding-top: 0.446em; padding-bottom: 0.593em;">(</span></span><span class="mjx-mi"><span class="mjx-char MJXc-TeX-math-I" style="padding-top: 0.225em;
